keyTakeAways: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP) has been without off-site power for four weeks, the longest blackout since the war began, forcing reliance on emergency diesel generators.
The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) confirmed that work to restore power began following the establishment of rare 'ceasefire zones' between Ukrainian and Russian forces.
Both Ukraine and Russia claim responsibility for the power outage: Ukraine accuses Russia of intentionally cutting the power to test reconnection; Russia blames Ukrainian shelling.
Restoration of off-site power is essential for nuclear safety, as the plant is vulnerable to radiation risks without stable electricity.
The Russian-controlled plant claims Russian defense ministry support is critical for repairs due to active shelling from Ukrainian forces.
This marks the 10th time since the war began that the ZNPP has lost grid connection, indicating a pattern of disruption.
Russia has continued targeting Ukraine’s energy infrastructure, including a strike on a substation in Slavutych that caused a blackout affecting the former Chernobyl plant.
Ukraine’s foreign minister accused Moscow of a 'deliberate strike' involving over 20 drones, citing awareness of the risks to Chernobyl.
The IAEA has been instrumental in facilitating dialogue and coordination between the warring sides to enable repair operations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Work is underway to restore power to the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP) in Ukraine, following the establishment of rare ceasefire zones between Russian and Ukrainian forces. The plant has been without off-site power for four weeks—the longest blackout since the war began—forcing it to rely on emergency diesel generators. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) confirmed that repairs to damaged power lines are now being carried out, with both sides accusing each other of causing the outage: Ukraine claims Russia intentionally cut power to test reconnection, while Russia blames Ukrainian shelling. This marks the 10th grid failure at ZNPP since the war began, and Russia has continued targeting Ukraine’s energy infrastructure, including a strike on a Slavutych substation that impacted the Chernobyl site. The IAEA has played a key role in mediating between the warring parties to allow safety-critical repairs to proceed, emphasizing the urgent need for nuclear safety and the risks posed by ongoing military aggression.
title: Work underway to restore power at Ukrainian nuclear plant as UN announces rare local ‘ceasefire zones’
